facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1954, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Civil Revision No. 183 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1954, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Civil Revision No. 183 of 1952. M. Lal and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for the appellant.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on September 12, 1960 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madhya Bharat at Gwalior

facts.text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madhya Bharat at Gwalior arising out of proceedings between a landlord (appellant) and his tenant (respondent) under the Accommodation Control Act XV of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madhya Bharat at Gwalior and arises out of proceedings between a landlord and his tenant taken under the Accommodation Control Act  XV of 1950  which, for the sake of brevity, will be termed the Act.

facts.text: On March 14, 1948, the appellant took two houses in Morar from the respondent at a monthly rental of Rs. 80 plus other charges at Rs. 5 per month.

anchor.surface_text: On March 14,1948, the appellant took two houses in Morar from the respondent at a monthly rental of Rs. 80 plus other charges at Rs. 5 per month. On October 20, 1948, the appellant brought a suit for- fixation of rent

facts.text: On October 20, 1948, the appellant brought a suit for fixation of rent in the court of the Cantonment Magistrate at Morar under the provisions of Accommodation Control Ordinance XX of 2004-S.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1948, the appellant brought a suit for- fixation of rent in the companyrt of the Cantonment Magistrate at Morar under the provisions of Accommodation Control Ordinance  Ordinance XX of 2004-S. . The Act was passed on January 25, 1950,

facts.text: The Accommodation Control Act XV of 1950 was passed on January 25, 1950, and came into force on February 10, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed on January 25, 1950, and came into force on February 10, 1950. Because of the passing of the Act the plaint was returned on March 20, 1950, for want of jurisdiction.

facts.text: Because of the passing of the Act, the plaint was returned on March 20, 1950, for want of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Because of the passing of the Act the plaint was returned on March 20, 1950, for want of jurisdiction. Thereupon on April 28, 1950, the appellant filed the suit before the Rent Controller out of which this appeal has arisen.

facts.text: On April 28, 1950, the appellant filed the suit before the Rent Controller praying for fixation of fair rent at Rs. 20 per month.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on April 28, 1950, the appellant filed the suit before the Rent Controller out of which this appeal has arisen. In the suit he prayed for the fixation of fair rent at Rs. 20 per month.

facts.text: The respondent pleaded that the suit could not be instituted before the Rent Controller and that the suit was incompetent because no notice under s. 7(2) of the Act had been given.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent pleaded inter alia that the suit companyld number be instituted before the Rent Controller and that the suit was incompetent because numbernotice under s. 7 2  of the Act had been given.

facts.text: Both pleas of the respondent were overruled by the Rent Controller.

anchor.surface_text: Both the pleas of the respondent were overruled and the Rent Controller held that the numberice which the appellant had given prior to the institution of the first suit was a proper numberice

facts.text: The Rent Controller held that the notice given by the appellant prior to the institution of the first suit was a proper notice and decreed the suit fixing fair rent at Rs. 483 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: and the Rent Controller held that the numberice which the appellant had given prior to the institution of the first suit was a proper numberice and he decreed the suit and fixed the fair rent at Rs. 483 per annum.

facts.text: The respondent took an appeal to the District Judge who upheld the order of the Rent Controller but the question of notice under s. 7 was not raised in that court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took an appeal to the District Judge who upheld the order of the Rent Controller but the question of numberice under s. 7 was number raised in that companyrt.

facts.text: The respondent filed a Revision Petition in the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed a Revision Petition in the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The High Court held that notice under s. 7 was a condition precedent to the institution of the suit and as no such notice was given the Rent Controller had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that numberice under s. 7 was a companydition precedent to the institution of the suit that as numbersuch numberice was given the Rent Controller had numberjurisdiction to make the order.

facts.text: The High Court held that the Rent Controller passed a decree which operated retrospectively from the date of the execution of the lease deed which the Controller had no authority to decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the Rent Controller had passed a decree which operated retrospectively from the date of the execution of the lease deed which the Controller had numberauthority to decree.

facts.text: The High Court held that the original suit was properly instituted in the civil court and the passing of the Act did not take away the jurisdiction of that court so the plaint should not have been returned.

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that the original suit was properly instituted in the civil companyrt and the passing of the Act did number take away the jurisdiction of that companyrt and therefore the civil companyrt should number have returned the plaint of the appellant.

facts.text: The trial court held that a proper notice had been given and therefore s. 7 was applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that a proper numberice had been given and therefore s. 7 was applicable. No such question was raised in appeal before the District Judge

facts.text: No question of notice under s. 7 was raised in appeal before the District Judge and therefore not adjudicated upon.

anchor.surface_text: No such question was raised in appeal before the District Judge and therefore it was number adjudicated upon. The question however was raised before the High Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the notice given by the appellant was a proper notice and s. 7(2) does not require notice after the Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it cannot be said that the numberice which was given by the appellant was number a proper numberice number does the section mean, as companytended by the respondent, that the numberice had to be given as under and after the Act came into force.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed, judgment of High Court set aside, and that of the trial court restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and that of the trial companyrt restored.
Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1954, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Civil Revision No. 183 of 1952.
The respondent then filed a Revision Petition in the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and under Art. 227 of the Constitution.
The respondent then filed a Revision Petition in the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madhya Bharat at Gwalior and arises out of proceedings between a landlord and his tenant taken under the Accommodation Control Act  XV of 1950  which, for the sake of brevity, will be termed the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question for decision is whether a suit companyld be instituted without a fresh numberice because of s. 7 2  of the Act ? That section provides Where numberrent for any such accommodation has been agreed upon or where the landlord wishes to enhance, or the tenant wishes to reduce the rent agreed upon, the landlord or the tenant, as the case may be, by giving numberice in writing to the other party shall proceed for having the rent fixed under subsection  4  All that this section companytemplates is that a numberice should be given. There are numberwords which make it obligatory that the numberice should be issued in terms as under the Act and be given after the Act came into force number has it prescribed any particular form.

concepts.interpretation: Notice given prior to the Act coming into force is proper and sufficient; no requirement for fresh notice after Act or specific form; only requires notice in writing

arguments.claim: Rent Controller order does not operate retrospectively but prospectively; jurisdiction in Rent Controller after Act

holdings.text: it cannot be said that the notice which was given by the appellant was not a proper notice nor does the section mean, as contended by the respondent, that the notice had to be given as under and after the Act came into force

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it cannot be said that the numberice which was given by the appellant was number a proper numberice number does the section mean, as companytended by the respondent, that the numberice had to be given as under and after the Act came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 7(2) contemplates only that notice in writing be given to the other party, with no words requiring issuance after Act's commencement or in any particular form

holdings.text: Fairly construed the order of the Rent Controller does not operate retrospectively from the date of the beginning of the lease but appears to us to be prospective and after the coming into operation of the Act the jurisdiction was vested in the Rent Controller and not in the civil court. This point therefore has no substance

anchor.surface_text: Lastly the High Court held that the plaint should number have been returned by the civil companyrt because the suit for fixation of fair rent related also to a period prior to the Act. Fairly companystrued the order of the Rent Controller does number operate retrospectively from the date of the beginning of the lease but appears to us to be prospective and after the companying into operation of the Act the jurisdiction was vested in the Rent Controller and number in the civil companyrt. This point therefore has numbersubstance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair construction of Rent Controller's order shows prospective effect; Act vests exclusive jurisdiction in Rent Controller post-commencement, requiring return of plaint from civil court

holdings.text: All that this section contemplates is that a notice should be given. There are no words which make it obligatory that the notice should be issued in terms as under the Act and be given after the Act came into force nor has it prescribed any particular form

anchor.surface_text: That section provides Where numberrent for any such accommodation has been agreed upon or where the landlord wishes to enhance, or the tenant wishes to reduce the rent agreed upon, the landlord or the tenant, as the case may be, by giving numberice in writing to the other party shall proceed for having the rent fixed under subsection  4  All that this section companytemplates is that a numberice should be given. There are numberwords which make it obligatory that the numberice should be issued in terms as under the Act and be given after the Act came into force number has it prescribed any particular form.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text of section 7(2) requires only notice in writing without mandating specific form, terms under Act, or post-enactment timing
